00002     @defgroup misc Miscellaneous

00012 
00013     @defgroup byteorder Byte Ordering
00014     @ingroup misc
00015     
00016     Utilities for swapping the order of bytes to match the Endianness of the required platform.
00017     An introduction to the issue of endianness can be found at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endianness.  
00018     
00019     Of particular relevance is that a Macintosh with a PPC processor uses a Big-endian byte ordering,
00020     whereas an Intel processor in a Mac or Windows machine will use a Little-endian byte ordering.
00021     
00022     These utilities are defined to assist with cases where byte ordering needs to be manipulated for floats or ints. 
00023     Note that floats are subject to the same byte ordering rules as integers. 
00024     While the IEEE defines the bits, the machine still defines how the bits are arranged with regard to bytes.
00025 
00026 
00027 
00028     @defgroup expr Extending expr
00029     @ingroup misc
00030     
00031     If you want to use C-like variable expressions that are entered by a user 
00032     of your object, you can use the “guts” of Max’s expr object in your 
00033     object. For example, the if object uses expr routines for evaluating a 
00034     conditional expression, so it can decide whether to send the message 
00035     after the words then or else. The following functions provide an 
00036     interface to expr.
00037     
00038     
00039     
00040     @defgroup tables Table Access
00041     @ingroup misc
00042     
00043     You can use these functions to access named table objects. Tables have 
00044     names when the user creates a table with an argument.
00045      
00046     The scenario for knowing the name of a table but not the object itself is 
00047     if you were passed a #t_symbol, either as an argument to your creation 
00048     function or in some message, with the implication being “do your 
00049     thing with the data in the table named norris.” 
00050     
00051     
00052     
00053     @defgroup texteditors Text Editor Windows
00054     @ingroup misc
00055     
00056     Max has a simple built-in text editor object that can display and 
00057     edit text in conjunction with your object. The routines described below 
00058     let you create a text editor.
00059     
00060     When the editor window is about to be closed, your object could 
00061     receive as many as three messages. The first one, okclose, will be sent if 
00062     the user has changed the text in the window. This is the standard 
00063     okclose message that is sent to all “dirty” windows when they are about 
00064     to be closed, but the text editor window object passes it on to you 
00065     instead of doing anything itself. Refer to the section on Window 
00066     Messages for a description of how to write a method for the okclose 
00067     message. It’s not required that you write one—if you don’t, the 
00068     behavior of the window will be determined by the setting of the 
00069     window’s w_scratch bit. If it’s set, no 
00070     confirmation will be asked when a dirty window is closed (and no 
00071     okclose message will be sent to the text editor either). The second 
00072     message, edclose, requires a method that should be added to your 
00073     object at initialization time. The third message, edSave, allows you to 
00074     gain access to the text before it is saved, or save it yourself.
00075     
00076     
00077     
00078     @defgroup presets Presets
00079     @ingroup misc
00080     
00081     Max contains a preset object that has the ability to send preset messages 
00082     to some or all of the objects (clients) in a Patcher window. The preset 
00083     message, sent when the user is storing a preset, is just a request for your 
00084     object to tell the preset object how to restore your internal state to what 
00085     it is now. Later, when the user executes a preset, the preset object will 
00086     send you back the message you had previously said you wanted.
00087     
00088     The dialog goes something like this: 
00089     
00090     - During a store…preset object to Client object(s): hello, this is the preset message—tell me how to restore your stateClient object to preset object: send me int 34 (for example) 
00091     - During an execute…preset object to Client object: int 34
00092     
00093     The client object won’t know the difference between receiving int 34 
00094     from a preset object and receiving a 34 in its leftmost inlet. 
00095     
00096     It’s not mandatory for your object to respond to the preset message, 
00097     but it is something that will make users happy. All Max user interface 
00098     objects currently respond to preset messages. Note that if your object is 
00099     not a user interface object and implements a preset method, the user 
00100     will need to connect the outlet of the preset object to its leftmost inlet 
00101     in order for it to be sent a preset message when the user stores a preset.
00102     
00103     Here’s an example of using preset_store() that specifies that the 
00104     object would like to receive a set message. We assume it has one field, 
00105     myvalue, which it would like to save and restore.
00106 
00107     @code
00108     void myobject_preset(myobject *x) 
00109     { 
00110         preset_store("ossl",x,ob_sym(x),gensym("set"),x->myvalue); 
00111     }
00112     @endcode
00113 
00114     When this preset is executed, the object will receive a set message 
00115     whose argument will be the value of myvalue. Note that the same 
00116     thing can be accomplished more easily with preset_set() and 
00117     preset_int().
00118 
00119     Don’t pass more than 12 items to preset_store(). If you want to store 
00120     a huge amount of data in a preset, use binbuf_insert().
00121 
00122     The following example locates the Binbuf into which the preset data is 
00123     being collected, then calls binbuf_insert() on a previously prepared 
00124     array of Atoms. It assumes that the state of your object can be restored 
00125     with a set message.
00126 
00127     @code
00128     void myobject_preset(myObject *x) 
00129     { 
00130         void *preset_buf;// Binbuf that stores the preset
00131         short atomCount; // number of atoms you’re storing
00132         t_atom atomArray[SOMESIZE];// array of atoms to be stored
00133     
00134         // 1. prepare the preset "header" information
00135         atom_setobj(atomArray,x); 
00136         atom_setsym(atomArray+1,ob_sym(x)); 
00137         atom_setsym(atomArray+2,gensym("set")); 
00138         // fill atomArray+3 with object's state here and set atomCount
00139     
00140         // 2. find the Binbuf
00141         preset_buf = gensym("_preset")->s_thing;
00142     
00143         // 3. store the data 
00144         if (preset_buf) { 
00145             binbuf_insert(preset_buf,NIL,atomCount,atomArray); 
00146         } 
00147     }
00148     @endcode
00149     
00150     
00151     
00152     
00153     @defgroup evnum Event and File Serial Numbers
00154     @ingroup misc
00155     
00156     If you call outlet_int(), outlet_float(), outlet_list(), or 
00157     outlet_anything() inside a Qelem or during some idle or interrupt 
00158     time, you should increment Max’s Event Serial Number beforehand. 
00159     This number can be read by objects that want to know if two messages 
00160     they have received occurred at the same logical “time” (in response to 
00161     the same event). Max increments the serial number for each tick of the 
00162     clock, each key press, mouse click, and MIDI event. Note that this is 
00163     different from the file serial number returned by the serialno() 
00164     function. The file serial number is only incremented when patchers are 
00165     saved in files. If more than one patcher is saved in a file, the file serial 
00166     number will change but the event serial number will not.
00167     
00168     @section using_event_serial_numbers Using Event Serial Numbers
00169     
00170     Here is a Max patch that includes an object called simul that would use 
00171     the information returned by evnum_get to return a 1 if the right and 
00172     left inlets receive messages at the same time, 0 if not. The number 
00173     boxes below show the results of clicking on the button objects or typing 
00174     a key.
00175     
00176     <img src="figures/event_serialno.png">
00177     
00178     
00179     
00180     @defgroup loading_max_files Loading Max Files
00181     @ingroup misc
00182     
00183     Several high-level functions permit you to load patcher files. These can 
00184     be used in sophisticated objects that use Patcher objects to perform 
00185     specific tasks.
00186     
00187
